Their extra money must come from the poorer classes, of course. It's an entitlement they have always enjoyed. Some of the money probably is being used to buy the congressmembers that pretend they are representing the rest of us too. But we are more than daft if we actually believe that.

Think about the actions they have already taken to reduce schooling for America's children in order to save money paid to teachers, especially the teachers of those citizens they would prefer to remain their permanently ignorant and poorly paid workhorses!

What would make Social Security whole again is for Congress to repay the SS Trust Fund the billions they have taken from it over the years to use for government spending that had nothing to do with SS.

That Trust Fund was supposed to be just that a Trust Fund for the hard working American people who paid into it and was supposed to be untouchable by the government.

All this Republican nonsense is dishonest and no part of it is positive for the average American worker. If SS was for the rich and wealthy, they would vote for it in a New York second. The sad part of it is the voters who support the Republicasns and vote for them are too dumb to realize the rightwing is sticking it to them too.
these republicans have become more than philosophically strident.  they have become evil.

So Republicans object to extending and expanding the payroll tax cut because unless it is paid for it will hurt the long term health of the SS fund and its beneficiaries (the elderly).

Fair enough - lets see how we can pay for it.

Republicans
Idea #1 Decrease entitlement programs (medicare and SS) which will of course hurt the elderly.
Idea #2 Cut federal jobs and freeze or cut salaries. That would be the salaries of Border Patrol, Homeland Security, INS, FAA etc.etc. In other words, cut the resources of those same agencies Republicans think we need more from.
Not to mention, adding more Americans to the unemployment rolls.

Democrats
Tax incomes over $1mil - about 350,000 Americans (versus 160 mil who would receive tax break from payroll tax cut).

Republicans object to Tax on the 350,000 because they are "job creators" - even though only about 1% of these 350,000 are small businesses.

And by the way, these small businesses who make over 1 mil would be helped by the cut in corporate payroll taxes as part of the suggested Democratic plan to extend the employer side of the tax.

Seems like Republicans have painted themselves into a corner. If this were a chessgame we would be at check - at least.

When a temporary tax cut for the rich is set to expire (e.g. the Bush tax cuts), Republicans call it a tax increase and they protest that they could never agree to a tax increase, so the rate must be extended. When the same thing is happening for the poor and middle class, a different standard applies, and it is suddenly acceptable to increase taxes for some unspecified reason.

The arguments offered by Republicans in this article for not extending the cut are ridiculously thin, even by Washington sound-byte standards. We're supposed to believe that they are suddenly concerned about the long term defensibility of the Social Security program? If it were politically feasible, they would eliminate it tomorrow, and everyone knows it. They've been trying to since the day Roosevelt signed it into law.

Obviously the poor and middle class will spend the money that they receive from the payroll tax break on goods and services, because they spend 95 cents or more of every dollar they earn. Even conservatives believe that consumer demand creates jobs, so that should help the economy, but for some reason Republicans just can't believe that giving money to anyone but wealthy "job creators" could be good for the economy. Well, the "job creators" have more money than any time in memory, and there are still no jobs. Either the part of the Republican brain responsible for logic is missing, or they are just shilling for the rich.

There is no such "savings account" or "lock box", Dave, as Al Gore will tell you. You support current beneficiaries with your contributions (and the half paid for you by your employer), and the next generation's contributions will support you. The scheme is brilliant, because it is inflation-proof and resilient even when there are market shocks. Your 401k is neither. Not even close. The Social Security Trust fund is just an abstraction that tracks the number of dollars that have been paid in against the number paid out. There is currently a large surplus. If there were ever a deficit in the fund, it could be used as a political argument for ending Social Security, but the program would not fold. People would continue to get their checks from the government.

It seems to me that the republicans are dead set on privatizing and profitizing everything they can lay their money grubbing hands on. But this is really going to far. Kids have to learn good study habits from day one and they can not get that without guidance from an adult.

There is no reason that a system like this cannot help some students but those students would need to be self motivated, more so than in a public school setting. Interaction with other students is very important as well, as being educated alone does not make a social being.

Sometimes I wonder what happens to all the money, all the profit, which is made by unscrupulous people. What of a practical, positive and helpful influence are they in our society?

After all the cacophony of a year and more, it will be a relief even to democrats to hear these conciliatory uttering. It would almost look as though the new GOP leader is one for real bipartisanship. On Medicare, social security, immigration reform, abortion, EPA, regulatory agencies, etc. he will grandly announce that while he admits that the GOP stand so far on these issues have been very adamant, he would say that democrats should not fight on these issues but follow a give and take policy. He would exhort one and all that these are all national issues and not party issues and should be decided by all people. He would say the last election was held in the backdrop of wars and did not reflect the real will of people. This election will be for real and it is not for him to define what is right and what is not before the election. If he is elected all people can certainly expect him to rule for all people, not only for Republicans,
Republicans in droves will vote for this guy, as democrats did for President Obama. Democrats would have by now very much exhausted their coffer and vented all their hate on those candidates who would not be any more in the field. Most likely the GOP candidate would be some father figure (or grand father figure) with a serene smile and slower movements, accompanied by a grand ma with a few wrinkles in her face. How could you talk even loudly in front of such a noble person without making people feel that you are a rowdy?

By February end mudslinging by all candidates, both Democrats and GOP, would have made a disgusting national display and the new GOP candidate will speak in a measured, leader-like tone on national issues. He would have gained in respect more by initially refusing to accept the offer and then reluctantly accepting it with the clearly expressed hope that the election would be fought on issues and not on personalities. He would only give a general outline of his vision, which anybody can think reflects his own views. He will avoid all controversial issues saying he did not have enough time to formulate his views and people should have faith in him to follow the constitution in all matters, whatever that may mean! He would avoid  commenting on GOP obstructionist policies of the last two years, saying he would rather discuss about the future, which we can change, rather than the past, which cannot be changed. He would even welcome suggestions from everyone, including democrats. He would say he has an open mind and may even accept some of the solutions suggested by President Obama, of course, after serious consideration and necessary modifications!
